TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed RouteDirection extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Indicates whether ASP.NET routing is processing a URL from a client or generating a URL.

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can use ASP.NET routing to process a URL by matching it to the route definitions in an ASP.NET application, or to generate URLs that are based on the route definitions. The <xref:System.Web.Routing.RouteDirection> enumeration provides values that help you differentiate between these scenarios. This is useful because route constraints are processed differently depending on the scenario. If you create a custom route constraint by implementing the <xref:System.Web.Routing.IRouteConstraint> interface, you might have to check the value of the `routeDirection` parameter in the <xref:System.Web.Routing.IRouteConstraint.Match%2A> method to differentiate the scenarios.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Web.Routing.RouteDirection IncomingRequest = int32(0)

Docs.summary: A URL from a client is being processed.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Web.Routing.RouteDirection UrlGeneration = int32(1)

Docs.summary: A URL is being created based on the route definition.
